César Milstein - My Favourite Scientist

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says it all.

X.T: Fossil Discoveries Challenge Ideas About Earth’s Start
X.ST: A series of fossil finds suggests that life on Earth started earlier than anyone thought, calling into question a widely held theory of the solar system’s beginnings.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The subtitle says it all.

X.T: [Éric Karsenti] Aux sources de la vie

X.T: It’s the End of the Gene As We Know It
X.ST: We are not nearly as determined by our genes as once thought.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Our understanding of genes has evolved and we now know that we are far from being fully defined by our DNA.

X.T: Math Reveals the Secrets of Cells’ Feedback Circuitry
X.ST: Maintaining perfect stability through negative feedback is a basic element of electrical circuitry, but it’s been a mystery how cells could do it — until now.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A mathematical proof of an integral control in a live being and a genetically engineered E. Coli.

X.T: Radioactivity May Fuel Life Deep Underground and Inside Other Worlds
X.ST: New work suggests that the radiolytic splitting of water supports giant subsurface ecosystems of life on Earth — and could do it elsewhere, too.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says it all.

X.T: Trace fossils, the most inconspicuous bite-sized window into ancient worlds
X.ST: “One animal could have made thousands of traces during its lifetime, but only left one skeleton."

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A presentation of ichnofossils, fossilised traces of animals.

X.T: How Humans Are Almost Identical to Chimps, According to DNA

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The differences between chimp and human DNA, and their impact.

X.T: DNA Has Four Bases. Some Viruses Swap in a Fifth.
X.ST: The DNA of some viruses doesn’t use the same four nucleotide bases found in all other life. New work shows how this exception is possible and hints that it could be more common than we think.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some bacteriophage viruses have adenine replaced by 2-aminoadenine in their DNA.

X.T: Animals Count and Use Zero. How Far Does Their Number Sense Go?
X.ST: Crows recently demonstrated an understanding of the concept of zero. It’s only the latest evidence of animals’ talents for numerical abstraction — which may still differ from our own grasp of numbers.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some research on how the brain of some animals manages numeracy.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A good presentation about viruses.

X.T: Why ‘De-Extinction’ Is Impossible (But Could Work Anyway)
X.ST: Several projects are aiming to bring back mammoths and other species that have vanished from the planet. Whether that’s technically possible is beside the point.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Because we miss some genes, we do not know how they are dispatched into chromosonme, we miss epigenomic data… it will probably be impossible to restore disapperead species, but de-extinction proponents claim this is not their objective.

X.T: Can We Program Our Cells?
X.ST: By genetically instructing cells to perform tasks that they wouldn’t in nature, synthetic biologists can learn deep secrets about how life works. Steven Strogatz discusses the potential of this young field with researcher Michael Elowitz.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: MichaelElowitz explains how he programs cells.

X.T: The Invisible Barrier Keeping Two Worlds Apart

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The Wallace line.

X.T: It's Raining Antibiotic Resistant Bacteria

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some bacteria having antibiotic resistance genes have been found in clouds.

X.T: Evolving Bacteria Can Evade Barriers to ‘Peak’ Fitness
X.ST: Paradoxically, natural selection can sometimes seem to block organisms from evolving useful adaptations. But a new study of “fitness landscapes” and antibiotic resistance in bacteria shows that life still finds a way.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A study of a very large population of E. Coli variants, having each a different gene, shows that most are able to evolve up to a state of antibiotic resistance.

X.T: Rarefaction curves and advanced mothematics .

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Evaluating the total number of species from the number of collected samples, but there is no mathematical modelisation here, only the use of rarefaction curves.

X.T: What Jumping Spiders Teach Us About Color

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An interesting description of the vision of jumping spiders.

X.T: Why Is It So Hard to Define a Species?
X.ST: The idea of a species is fundamental to the way that many people understand the structure of life on Earth. But ask 10 specialists how they define the concept and you might get 10 answers. In this episode, co-host Janna Levin speaks with evolutionary biologist Kevin de Queiroz about what makes defining and delineating species such a slippery process, and why it matters to our understanding of both evolution and conservation.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says it all: there is still no agreement on the definition of "species."

X.T: How Is Cell Death Essential to Life?
X.ST: Cells in our bodies are constantly dying — and these countless tiny deaths are essential to human health and multicellular life itself. In this episode, co-host Steven Strogatz speaks with cellular biologist Shai Shaham about what makes a cell “alive” and the latest developments in understanding how and why cells die.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: There is a lot of interesting information about how and why cells die in this interview.

X.T: Mirror Molecules: The Symmetry Rule Life Never Breaks

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The homochirality of life: what it is, how it may have appeared, mirror life…

X.T: Does Form Really Shape Function?
X.ST: From brain folds to insect architecture, L. Mahadevan explains how complex biological forms and behaviors emerge through the interplay of physical forces, environment and embodiment.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The subtitle says it all.

X.T: How Could Life Evolve From Cyanide?
X.ST: How did life arise on Earth? Steven Strogatz speaks with the Nobel Prize-winning biologist Jack Szostak and Betül Kaçar, a paleogeneticist and astrobiologist, to explore our best understanding of how we all got here.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A description of the RNA world hypothesis, and trying to determine ancient genes and experimenting with the corresponding artificial DNA in modern bacteria.

X.T: What Can Cave Life Tell Us About Alien Ecosystems?
X.ST: Extremophiles, or microbes that live in the most seemingly hostile environments, are the darlings of astrobiologists, who study the potential for life beyond Earth. In this episode, co-host Janna Levin speaks with astrobiologist and cave explorer Penelope Boston about how life finds a way — and whether it might have found a way elsewhere in our solar system or around a distant star.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: PenelopeBoston speaks about her interest for organisms living in caves and for astrobiology.

X.T: How Will We Know We’re Not Alone?
X.ST: The first planet beyond our solar system was identified just 30 years ago. Since then, thousands have been found and characterized. As we look for more, exoplanet experts are also probing for signs of alien biospheres hundreds of light-years away. In this episode, co-host Janna Levin speaks with astrophysicist and astrobiologist Lisa Kaltenegger about how we’ll know we’re not alone in the cosmos.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The basics of the search for extraterrestrial life.

X.T: La vie secrète des arbres : la théorie s’effondre
X.ST: L’idée est si émouvante qu’elle a conquis le public, Hollywood, et jusqu’aux plus hautes institutions : les arbres communiqueraient via un réseau secret… Sauf que c’est faux. Les scientifiques ont beau chercher, ils n’en trouvent aucune trace. Et pour eux, cette théorie est dangereuse pour la forêt.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: No study confirms SuzannePihen’s claim that trees "help" one each other by exchanging nutriments via mycelium.
